Journal of Diabetes Investigation https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ This is an open access article under the terms of the http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ ABSTRACT Aims/Introduction The sex‐specific association between alcohol consumption and glycemic level and whether the association differs by genetic susceptibility to alcohol is unclear. The present study aimed to examine the association of alcohol consumption and genetic variants in alcohol‐metabolizing enzymes with glycemic level, as well as their sex differences, in East Asian individuals with type 2 diabetes. Materials and Methods In total, 4,923 Japanese individuals with type 2 diabetes were included. Participants were classified based on alcohol drinking status, alcohol consumption amount (<20, 20–39, or ≥40 g/day), and ADH1B (rs1229984) and ALDH2 (rs671) genotype, and the associations with HbA 1c Results In men, compared with never drinkers, an increase in the alcohol consumption amount was associated with a decrease in HbA 1c P 1c 1c 1c P 1c 1c Conclusions These findings highlight the importance of a sex‐specific approach to alcohol drinking habits in managing glycemic control for individuals with type 2 diabetes, irrespective of genetic predisposition to alcohol metabolism. In East Asian individuals with type 2 diabetes, increases in alcohol consumption were inversely associated with HbA1c levels in men, whereas the amount of alcohol consumption was associated with HbA1c levels in a J‐shaped manner in women. The alcohol–HbA1c associations were similarly observed, regardless of genetic susceptibility to alcohol metabolism. The present findings highlight the importance of a sex‐specific approach to alcohol drinking habits in the clinical practice of diabetes management, irrespective of the genetic predisposition to alcohol metabolism. Aldehyde dehydrogenase‐2 (ALDH2) is a key enzyme involved in the detoxification of acetaldehyde  7  7  7  8  9  10  11  12  13 The present study thus aimed to examine the associations of alcohol consumption and genetic variants in alcohol‐metabolizing enzymes with glycemic control, as well as their sex differences in East Asian individuals with type 2 diabetes. In addition, we examined whether the association between alcohol consumption and glycemic control differs by ADH1B and ALDH2 genotype. METHODS Study design and population The Fukuoka Diabetes Registry is a multicenter prospective cohort study that was designed to examine the influence of contemporary treatments on the prognosis of individuals with diabetes regularly attending teaching hospitals or diabetes clinics certified by the Japan Diabetes Society in Fukuoka Prefecture, Japan  14 Clinical evaluation and laboratory measurements Participants completed a self‐administered questionnaire regarding their medical history, medication use, and lifestyle factors, including alcohol drinking habits, dietary habits, smoking, and leisure‐time physical activity (LTPA). Dietary habits were assessed using a brief‐type self‐administered diet history questionnaire (Gender Medical Research Inc., Tokyo, Japan) based on the frequency of consumption of 58 items, which has been validated for ranking nutrient intakes in Japanese adults  15 n n  15  16  17 1c 2  18 Statistical analysis Participant characteristics based on alcohol drinking status and ADH1B and ALDH2 genotypes are presented as the mean (standard deviation) for continuous variables and number (percentage) for categorical variables. The amount of alcohol consumption was linearly associated with decreased HbA 1c 1c Previous meta‐analyses of observational studies showed the J‐shaped association between alcohol intake and the risk of type 2 diabetes; there was a decreased risk with a moderate amount of alcohol intake compared with abstainers, while there was an increased risk with heavy drinking  9  4 1c  4  3 1c The reason for the inconsistencies with the previous findings was unclear, but it may be due to sex differences in alcohol pharmacokinetics. The lower first‐pass metabolism of alcohol  19  6  6  20  21  20  21  6  3  4 In terms of alcohol‐metabolizing enzymes, several studies examined the association between the ALDH2 genotype and diabetes. A meta‐analysis of genome‐wide association studies conducted in East Asian individuals showed that ALDH2 genetic polymorphism was associated with type 2 diabetes in men but not in women  8  12  22  8  11 1c S4  8  7  23  24  10  11  12  10  12  11 Several previous studies examined whether the effects of alcohol consumption on glycemic levels were modified by genetic susceptibility to alcohol. A population‐based cohort study in Chinese older participants found a J‐shaped association between alcohol drinking and the risk of type 2 diabetes, and the association did not vary by genetic polymorphisms of the ADH1B and ALDH2 genes  25  12  11  11 1c 3  26 The strengths of the current study include the recruitment of the study population from East Asia, where individuals with diabetes are rapidly increasing and genetic variants in the ADH1B and ALDH2 genes are highly prevalent. In addition, the separate assessment of men and women enabled us to clarify sex differences in the association between alcohol consumption and glycemic control. Furthermore, the relatively large number of participants allowed us to adjust for multiple confounders, including dietary factors and physical activity. Although these habits were closely related to both alcohol drinking and glycemic levels, few studies have considered them as confounding factors. The uniform collection of blood samples and their measurement in a central laboratory minimized the potential for measurement errors. However, some limitations should be discussed. First, all the participants were recruited from the Kyushu region, Japan. The prevalence of ALDH2 polymorphisms varies not only by ethnicity but also by region, even within Japan  27  28 In conclusion, increases in alcohol consumption were inversely associated with HbA 1c 1c 1c DISCLOSURE The authors declare that they have no competing interests.
